Articles.Content:
Hey Yanfret, I was wondering if you're planing to update some parts of the mod sometime to incorporate the current road map for mars, I mean, nuclear propulsion has been dropped long ago by NASA, and the Mars mission will be either solar or nuclear powered electric propulsion (have you read "The Martian"?). Please don't get me wrong, I love this pack and your texturing skills are awesome, just wondering if an updated Mars/Duna mission will get the "Yanfret/Chaka" treatment.

Cheers

Edited April 21, 2015 by Drakenex
I'm all for it, but how would we simulate long duration SEP burns in KSP without doing it in real time?

Hey Yanfret, I was wondering if you're planing to update some parts of the mod sometime to incorporate the current road map for mars, I mean, nuclear propulsion has been dropped long ago by NASA, and the Mars mission will be either solar or nuclear powered electric propulsion (have you read "The Martian"?). Please don't get me wrong, I love this pack and your texturing skills are awesome, just wondering if an updated Mars/Duna mission will get the "Yanfret/Chaka" treatment.

http://www.nasa.gov/sites/default/files/thumbnails/image/journey_to_mars.jpeg

http://fc03.deviantart.net/fs70/f/2014/271/e/4/hermes_from__the_martian__by_francisdrakex-d80sys7.jpg

http://th00.deviantart.net/fs71/PRE/i/2014/271/a/e/hermes_leaving_earth_by_francisdrakex-d80t79h.jpg

Cheers

Love love love the Martian! Incredible book! I hope they don't ruin the movie that's supposed to come out late this year I think.
Could see about picking up anther engine mount from Constellation Essentials the house the 6 x RS-68B well, I made it house 7

I'm all for it, but how would we simulate long duration SEP burns in KSP without doing it in real time?

Just up the thrust for the sake of convenience. Also, I know the SEP spacecraft used some form of chemical booster (like the upper stage of the Mars lander shown in the Boeing infographic) to get going, as well.

Just up the thrust for the sake of convenience. Also, I know the SEP spacecraft used some form of chemical booster (like the upper stage of the Mars lander shown in the Boeing infographic) to get going, as well.

Yeah but if it's that easy then I have to make it

Well I guess my point is that a large scale SEP to duna system as depicted by Boeing would burn for half the distance to Mars and the transfer orbit would not be similar to a boost then coast shape curve, so if we up the thrust we're really just simulating the NTR system with different efficiency, and that seems a little surface somehow.

Yes! that's a big issue, in RL the ship only accelerates half the trip and decelerates the other half, both things can't be simulated.

With my nuclear powered-Ion propelled near future prototype, trans-duna injection takes 9 minutes, so may be with more engines (40 Ion / 20 cluster) it takes less time and the injection will be less boring (I just went for some coffee )

Love love love the Martian! Incredible book! I hope they don't ruin the movie that's supposed to come out late this year I think.

Yes!! I couldn't put it down until I finished it, It's a must read for any Mars missions enthusiast. The movie is supposed to release on November 25th and is on post-production, but the lack of a trailer, interviews and a poster is very strange or may be I'm looking at the wrong places!
HEHE monkey around

Yeah but if it's that easy then I have to make it

Well I guess my point is that a large scale SEP to duna system as depicted by Boeing would burn for half the distance to Mars and the transfer orbit would not be similar to a boost then coast shape curve, so if we up the thrust we're really just simulating the NTR system with different efficiency, and that seems a little surface somehow.

May I present your

Revised Chaka SLS Model

EDIT: scroll down for latest update

Edited April 27, 2015 by YANFRET
HEHE where is that monkey shine on the upper tank ?

Revised

http://imageshack.com/a/img673/4757/19jkQK.jpg

Don't get me wrong please. I love the way it looks and I am sure you have gone through painstaking efforts to get it to look like this but idk. To me it looks a bit stretched. It looks too long. I know the SLS is an enormous rocket! However like I said it look too stretched. If you are going by that picture I am afraid you are making it too long because of the angle. If you look at the mock up picture the camera would be positioned on a tripod or at eye level of a standard human. That SLS is most likely pasted over a Space Shuttle rollout. So you have to imagine that there is an immense angle to the picture. So if you are stretching your model based on this picture because of the angle your end result will end up looking stretched. Both of your comparison shots are straight on. Compare them straight on but from what would be the height of a kerbal or human looking up at a similar difference. Anyway it really does look good albeit in my opinion a little stretched. Its probably just me.

Edited April 26, 2015 by sp1989

Yeah, you may be right. Part of that is the chase persepcitve, but I think we're still about 3% off in some areas. I'm gonna refine it again.

Edited April 26, 2015 by YANFRET

Choices and Options

Here is a new version that is roughly 4% shorter than what I had posted above before

And it's scaled here with two official and reputable sources. In this example, the Chaka model is somewhat shorter than one reference, however I think it would visually look better in KSP.

Do you guys think it looks good like this or should we stretch it up more?

Edited April 27, 2015 by YANFRET

It may just be a lack of the detailing (flags, country names, external oxidiser pipe location) on the sides that it look stretched, there's more white space. Along with the perspective it's hard to tell if it really is stretched or squashed.

It may just be a lack of the detailing (flags, country names, external oxidiser pipe location) on the sides that it look stretched, there's more white space. Along with the perspective it's hard to tell if it really is stretched or squashed.

I agree but I also think that main stage is too tall. I think if it was shortened thatt would put everything else into perspective better. Also the interstage is too tall as well. What interesting is I think from the interstage up everything is ok. I know its probably alot of work to be toying around but what if you made the the core stage and interstage like 5% shorter. Then adjusted the srbs accordingly. I don't know it just all looks sligthtly stretched.

I agree but I also think that main stage is too tall. I think if it was shortened thatt would put everything else into perspective better. Also the interstage is too tall as well. What interesting is I think from the interstage up everything is ok. I know its probably alot of work to be toying around but what if you made the the core stage and interstage like 5% shorter. Then adjusted the srbs accordingly. I don't know it just all looks sligthtly stretched.

Edited April 27, 2015 by YANFRET
Does anybody know is this pack is compatible with 1.0? Would really love to start using it to explore again!

Does anybody know is this pack is compatible with 1.0? Would really love to start using it to explore again!

This may sound crazy, but you could test it yourself. I will say this, if it uses the old node system it won't work unless you use the cheat to ignore node direction. Also, with the changes to atmosphere, the DV and TWR values are going to be far too high. They will all need to be adjusted.
